ratings.comment: Really interesting class, lectures were pretty engaging. One paper as the final that you get a lot of feedback on before you submit it.
Great professor who cares about student learning and always willing to help.
The way this class is formatted is really bad. The grading is completely arbitrary and he makes it seem like he is better than everyone. He can never admit that he was wrong.
Professor Nirshberg was passionate about the material. There was a decent amount of reading, but it was always interesting and the lectures engaging. Overall, a great course!

Professor Nirshberg is a very understanding professor who shows a real passion for philosophy. His entire teaching style revolves around class discussion and participation which I really enjoyed. Nirshberg does a great job at finding the value in all student's comments and questions. He is great at promoting interesting conversations.

Straight up do not take this class. Greg actually makes lecture decent to go to, but his grading is TERRIBLE. The TA has NO idea how to grade and the discussions are run SO poorly, yet Greg has no motivation to make a change. The papers are graded both harshly and unfairly, even if you put in the effort and got the right answer.

Nirshberg was super layed back, always down to help if I had questions, was always willing to stay after class and talked. Super knowledgeable about his subject and respectful toward his students. Awesome class discussions that helped me understand material. Participation was super important. Lot of complicated readings, but they were always fun.
Really awesome dude. Loves his subject and is always down to talk to his students. Articulates concepts well.

Professor Nirshberg is pretty great and his class (Philosophy 101) is pretty interesting overall. I have no complaints with his teaching style or the way the material was taught in class. But the thing is there are so many long and boring papers you have to write for which they grade you pretty harshly so getting an A is pretty tough

Greg is a fantastic teacher and educator of philosophy. He offers constructive criticism as well as way to help grow as a philosopher and learner. If given the chance take one of his courses. They are ran well with participation in the best of ways.

My class had Greg replace our TA after she had to quit. Greg is very knowledgable, but his knowledge is coupled with a big ego. He was condescending in all of my conversations with him. Feedback on papers is harsh and rude. "This conclusion is perfunctory" and "I mean, I'm not sure she means it to work like this, but okay."
Greg is a nice guy and did a good job teaching tough material. 9 problem sets plus 2 midterms and a non-cumulative final.
